title: HSV Encephalitis
scope: ** Acute HSV-1 encephalitis in adults — the most common cause of sporadic fatal encephalitis. Covers emergent empiric acyclovir, LP with HSV PCR, MRI findings, seizure management, and monitoring for complications (cerebral edema, SIADH, refractory status epilepticus). Excludes neonatal HSV, HSV-2 meningitis (Mollaret), CMV/EBV/VZV encephalitis, and autoimmune encephalitis (though post-HSV autoimmune encephalitis is addressed).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; infection markers; lymphopenia may be present
Renal function for acyclovir dosing (nephrotoxic); electrolytes (SIADH); hepatic function
Before LP; coagulopathy workup if DIC suspected
Low procalcitonin argues against bacterial meningitis
Inflammatory marker; lower in viral than bacterial
SIADH is common complication of HSV encephalitis
Potential surgical intervention for mass effect

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Seroconversion supports diagnosis; IgG positive in most adults (not diagnostic alone); IgM suggests acute infection
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Rising titers on paired sera (acute + convalescent at 2-4 weeks)

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Immunocompromise affects prognosis and treatment duration
SIADH confirmation (urine osm >100, urine Na >40 with low serum Na)
Stress cardiomyopathy; myocarditis in systemic viral illness

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Autoimmune encephalitis panel (serum) — NMDAR, LGI1, CASPR2 (CPT 86255)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Post-HSV autoimmune encephalitis occurs in 20-27% (especially anti-NMDAR); also primary differential
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Negative initially; recheck at 2-4 weeks if relapse

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: If atypical features or oncologic history

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Arboviral serologies (West Nile, EEE, St. Louis)

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Animal exposure history with rapidly progressive encephalitis

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated in some cases; monitor for ICP issues
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal or mildly elevated (usually <300 mm H2O)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Lymphocytic pleocytosis typical; RBCs may be present (hemorrhagic encephalitis); tube comparison for traumatic tap
Lumbar Puncture.target: WBC 10-500 cells/µL (lymphocyte predominant); RBC may be elevated (hemorrhagic necrosis)
Elevated (50-200 mg/dL typical; can be higher)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Usually NORMAL in HSV (distinguishes from bacterial/TB/fungal)
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal (>60% serum glucose ratio); low glucose argues against HSV

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: GOLD STANDARD diagnostic test; sensitivity 96-98%, specificity ~99%. May be NEGATIVE in first 72h — if clinical suspicion high and initial PCR negative, REPEAT at 3-7 days
Lumbar Puncture.target: Positive (HSV-1 in >90% adult cases; HSV-2 in neonatal/meningitis)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Rapid multiplex PCR — includes HSV-1/2, VZV, enterovirus, CMV, HHV-6, and bacterial pathogens; result in ~1 hour
VZV encephalitis in differential; especially immunocompromised and elderly
Lumbar Puncture.target: Negative (positive → VZV encephalitis — treat with IV acyclovir)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Post-transplant encephalitis; temporal lobe involvement similar to HSV

Lumbar Puncture.item: Autoimmune encephalitis panel (CSF) — NMDAR, LGI1, CASPR2, GABA-B
Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Primary differential diagnosis; also detect post-HSV autoimmune encephalitis
TB meningitis if subacute or basilar

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate — before LP to exclude mass effect; CT may be NORMAL early in HSV encephalitis
Essential/First-line.target: Temporal lobe hypodensity, edema, hemorrhage (late); may be normal in first 48-72h

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24h; STAT if available. MOST SENSITIVE imaging study — abnormal in >90% within 48h
Essential/First-line.target: T2/FLAIR hyperintensity in medial temporal lobes (unilateral or bilateral), insular cortex, inferior frontal gyri, cingulate gyrus. DWI restriction in acute phase. Hemorrhagic transformation. Leptomeningeal enhancement

Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24h; continuous EEG if altered consciousness
Essential/First-line.target: Periodic lateralizing epileptiform discharges (PLEDs/LPDs) from temporal region — highly suggestive of HSV encephalitis; focal slowing; electrographic seizures; diffuse slowing
Baseline; myocarditis screen; QTc for medication interactions

Extended.target: Venous sinus thrombosis; vasculopathy; large vessel occlusion

Extended.timing: At 48-72h if initial MRI negative but suspicion high; at 7-14 days to assess extent of damage
Extended.target: Evolving temporal changes; hemorrhagic transformation; extent of necrosis

Extended.timing: 24-72h minimum if altered consciousness, seizures, or post-ictal state
Extended.target: Non-convulsive seizures, non-convulsive status epilepticus (NCSE), PLEDs

Rare/Specialized.timing: Only if: PCR negative, MRI atypical, no response to acyclovir, alternative diagnosis likely
Rare/Specialized.target: Cowdry type A inclusions; viral culture; PCR on tissue

Rare/Specialized.timing: If autoimmune encephalitis relapse suspected post-HSV
Rare/Specialized.target: Mesial temporal hypermetabolism (seizure focus) or hypometabolism

Rare/Specialized.timing: If clinical signs of elevated ICP; declining GCS despite treatment

Acute/Emergent.indication: Empiric antiviral for suspected or confirmed HSV encephalitis

dosing.instructions: 10 mg/kg IV q8h (infuse over 1h). Base on IDEAL body weight (IBW). Duration: minimum 14-21 days. Dose adjust for renal impairment: CrCl 25-50: 10 mg/kg q12h; CrCl 10-25: 10 mg/kg q24h; HD: 10 mg/kg after each dialysis session

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: True acyclovir allergy (extremely rare). Renal impairment — dose adjust, do NOT withhold
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Renal function (BUN, Cr) daily; ensure adequate hydration (1-1.5 mL/kg/h IV fluids); urine output; acyclovir crystal nephropathy (maintain urine output); CBC (rare neutropenia); LFTs

Acute/Emergent.indication: Prevent acyclovir crystal nephrotoxicity with aggressive hydration

dosing.instructions: 1-1.5 mL/kg/h continuous to prevent acyclovir nephrotoxicity; bolus 500-1000 mL if dehydrated

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: I/O; Cr daily; urine output >0.5 mL/kg/h

Acute/Emergent.indication: Empiric bacterial meningitis coverage until excluded by CSF results

dosing.instructions: Standard meningitis dosing. Continue until bacterial meningitis excluded by CSF results (Gram stain negative, BioFire negative, cultures negative at 48-72h). See Bacterial Meningitis template for dosing

Acute/Emergent.indication: Empiric adjunctive steroid with antibiotics until bacterial meningitis excluded

dosing.instructions: 0.15 mg/kg IV q6h x 4 days — give empirically with antibiotics until bacterial meningitis excluded. Discontinue when bacterial excluded. Role in HSV encephalitis itself is CONTROVERSIAL — some evidence for reducing edema but no clear mortality benefit; not standard of care for isolated HSV

Acute/Emergent.indication: First-line antiepileptic for acute symptomatic seizures in HSV encephalitis

dosing.instructions: 1000-1500 mg IV load; then 500-1000 mg IV/PO BID; max 3000 mg/day. Seizures occur in 40-60% of HSV encephalitis

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute seizure termination and rescue therapy

dosing.instructions: 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg); repeat x1 in 5 min if needed

Acute/Emergent.indication: Maintain oxygenation if SpO2 below 94% or patient intubated

dosing.instructions: If SpO2 <94% or intubated
650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h; max 4g/day
1-1.5 g/kg IV bolus; then 0.25-0.5 g/kg q4-6h
30 mL IV via central line over 10-20 min
0.5-1 mL/kg/h continuous; target Na 145-155
Fosphenytoin 20 mg PE/kg IV at 150 mg PE/min; maintenance 100 mg PE q8h; target level 10-20 µg/mL

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Continuous telemetry during load; free phenytoin level; LFTs

dosing.instructions: 200 mg IV/PO load; then 100-200 mg BID; max 400 mg/day
4 mg IV/PO q6h PRN

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: GI prophylaxis (if steroids or critical illness)

dosing.instructions: 40 mg IV/PO daily
40 mg SC daily (start when not actively seizing and no hemorrhagic transformation)

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Active bleeding, hemorrhagic transformation, coagulopathy, platelets <50K

dosing.instructions: Apply bilaterally on admission
1-1.2 L/day if Na <130 with clinical SIADH

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Second-line antiviral for acyclovir-resistant HSV in immunocompromised patients

dosing.instructions: 60 mg/kg IV q8h or 90 mg/kg IV q12h; infuse over 1-2h with aggressive hydration. For proven or suspected acyclovir resistance (immunocompromised, HIV)

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Cr daily; Ca, Mg, K, PO4 BID (causes severe electrolyte wasting); hydration 1-2 L NS before each dose

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Malignant cerebral edema with impending herniation refractory to medical therapy

dosing.instructions: For malignant cerebral edema with impending herniation, unresponsive to medical ICP management; consider if age appropriate and prognosis not already dismal

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Post-op neuro checks; ICP monitoring; wound care

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Post-HSV autoimmune encephalitis with confirmed anti-NMDAR antibodies

doseOptions.orderSentence: Immunotherapy for post-HSV autoimmune encephalitis 1g/day IV

dosing.instructions: If relapse at 2-6 weeks with new anti-NMDAR antibodies: IV methylprednisolone 1g/day x 5 days + IVIG 0.4 g/kg/day x 5 days; second-line: rituximab
dosing.orderSentence: Immunotherapy for post-HSV autoimmune encephalitis 1g/day IV

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Active HSV infection (ensure viral replication controlled)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: NMDAR antibody titers; clinical response; viral PCR to confirm HSV not reactivated

Duration of Treatment and Discontinuatio.criteria to stop: Clinical improvement; repeat LP at end of treatment — if HSV PCR still positive, continue additional 7 days

Duration of Treatment and Discontinuatio.duration: Consider stopping at 7-10 days if: two negative HSV PCRs (initial + repeat at 3-7 days), MRI not consistent with HSV, alternative diagnosis established

Duration of Treatment and Discontinuatio.criteria to stop: Repeat LP with PCR before stopping; ensure negative PCR before discontinuation

Duration of Treatment and Discontinuatio.duration: Oral valacyclovir 1g PO TID x 3-6 months after IV course is INVESTIGATIONAL; some centers use for immunocompromised; not standard of care

Referrals & Consults.indication: All suspected encephalitis; seizure management; EEG interpretation; post-HSV autoimmune evaluation
Antimicrobial management; acyclovir-resistant HSV; duration of therapy
Cerebral edema with mass effect; ICP monitoring (EVD placement); decompressive craniectomy
Altered consciousness (GCS <12); respiratory failure; ICP management; status epilepticus
Dysphagia evaluation; aphasia assessment (temporal lobe involvement); cognitive-communication evaluation
Early mobilization; prevent deconditioning; gait/balance training
ADL assessment; cognitive rehabilitation; memory aids
Cognitive assessment (memory deficits common with temporal lobe damage); rehabilitation planning
Behavioral changes; depression; anxiety; personality changes (frontal/temporal damage)
Family support; discharge planning; long-term care needs
Post-encephalitis epilepsy management; temporal lobe epilepsy
Goals of care for severe cases; prognostication

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED if: new confusion, seizure, fever recurrence, worsening headache, personality change, speech difficulty, new weakness
HSV encephalitis can cause long-term memory and cognitive deficits; rehabilitation is important
Seizures may develop weeks to months after infection; report any episodic symptoms (staring, jerking, déjà vu, loss of awareness)
Post-HSV autoimmune encephalitis can occur 2-6 weeks later with new psychiatric/neurologic symptoms — report immediately
Take all medications as prescribed; do NOT stop antiepileptic drugs without neurologist guidance
Follow-up with neurology in 2-4 weeks; neuropsychology testing at 3-6 months
Cognitive rehabilitation and therapy are critical for recovery
Driving restrictions until seizure-free per state law (typically 3-12 months)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: HSV encephalitis is NOT contagious in the traditional sense; no isolation needed
Long-term suppressive antiviral therapy is NOT standard after encephalitis (unlike genital HSV)
Cognitive rehabilitation: memory strategies, organizational tools, speech therapy
Seizure safety: avoid heights, swimming alone, operating heavy machinery until seizure-free
Mental health support (depression, anxiety, PTSD common after encephalitis)
Gradual return to work/school with accommodations as needed

differential.features: Subacute; psychiatric symptoms (psychosis, agitation); orofacial dyskinesias; seizures; young women; often post-HSV
differential.tests: Anti-NMDAR antibody (CSF > serum); MRI may be normal or temporal; ovarian teratoma screen

differential.features: Fever + meningismus; CSF neutrophilic pleocytosis with low glucose; more acute; no temporal preference on imaging
differential.tests: CSF Gram stain, culture, BioFire; procalcitonin elevated; CSF glucose low

differential.features: Headache + fever + meningismus; LESS confusion/focal deficits; CSF lymphocytic but fewer WBC; MRI normal
differential.tests: Enterovirus PCR (CSF); BioFire panel; normal MRI

differential.features: Immunocompromised; may have rash (but not always); vasculopathy pattern on MRI; cranial neuropathies
differential.tests: VZV PCR (CSF); VZV IgG intrathecal antibody

differential.features: Seizures may cause MRI signal change in temporal lobes mimicking encephalitis; fever if convulsive SE
differential.tests: EEG; HSV PCR negative; MRI DWI pattern; clinical course

differential.features: Subacute memory loss, seizures, psychiatric changes; often >40 years; associated malignancy
differential.tests: Antibody panel (serum + CSF); CT chest/abdomen/pelvis; PET-CT

differential.features: Headache, seizures, focal deficits; papilledema; risk factors (OCPs, hypercoagulable)
Focal symptoms + fever; ring-enhancing lesion; subacute
differential.tests: MRI with contrast (ring enhancement, restricted DWI centrally); blood cultures

differential.features: Post-infectious; multifocal white matter lesions; children > adults
Subacute (weeks); basilar meningitis; CSF low glucose, lymphocytic, very high protein
differential.tests: AFB culture; TB PCR; ADA; chest imaging

differential.features: Subacute; psychiatric symptoms; pupillary abnormalities; history of STI
Immunocompromised; progressive focal deficits; periventricular enhancing lesion
differential.tests: MRI with contrast; CSF cytology; EBV PCR (CSF); brain biopsy

evidence.recommendation: IV acyclovir 10 mg/kg q8h x 14-21 days
evidence.source: [Whitley et al. (NEJM 1986)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/3001520/) — acyclovir vs placebo landmark trial; reduced mortality from 70% to 20%

evidence.recommendation: Start acyclovir empirically; do NOT delay for diagnostics
evidence.source: [IDSA Encephalitis Guidelines](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18582201/) ([Tunkel et al. CID 2008](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18582201/)); every hour of delay worsens outcomes

evidence.recommendation: CSF HSV PCR as gold standard (sensitivity 96-98%)
Repeat HSV PCR if initially negative with high clinical suspicion
evidence.source: False negative rate ~5% in first 72h; Roullet (2007)

evidence.recommendation: MRI with DWI is most sensitive imaging

evidence.source: Periodic lateralizing discharges in ~80% of HSV encephalitis
[Armangue et al. (Ann Neurol 2014)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24318406/); [Prüss et al. (Ann Neurol 2012)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23280840/)

evidence.recommendation: Dexamethasone for HSV encephalitis: NOT standard of care
evidence.source: DexEnceph trial (ongoing); animal data supportive; no clear human mortality benefit

evidence.recommendation: Aggressive hydration to prevent acyclovir nephrotoxicity

evidence.source: Standard practice; cannot clinically distinguish bacterial meningitis from encephalitis at presentation

evidence.recommendation: Repeat LP at end of treatment to confirm PCR negativity

evidence.source: IDSA Guidelines; relapse rate higher with <14 days

monitoring.frequency: q1h x 24h, then q2h x 48h, then q4h
monitoring.action: If declining: STAT CT; ICP assessment; consider EVD
Acetaminophen; cooling measures; reassess if persistent fever >72h on acyclovir
If <130: SIADH → fluid restriction (balance with acyclovir hydration); if <120: 3% saline
If rising: increase hydration; consider dose adjustment; hold if severe (rare); monitor urine output

monitoring.frequency: q1h in ICU; q4h shift on floor
monitoring.action: Increase IV fluids; if oliguria: renal assessment

monitoring.frequency: cEEG 24-72h if altered consciousness; routine EEG daily if improving
monitoring.action: If seizures: load/adjust AEDs; if NCSE: aggressive treatment per SE protocol

monitoring.frequency: Continuous in ICU; q4h on floor
monitoring.action: Supplemental O2; intubation if respiratory failure

monitoring.frequency: At 48-72h (evolution); day 7-14 (extent of damage); 3-6 months (chronic changes)
monitoring.action: If worsening edema: ICP management; neurosurgery consult

monitoring.frequency: At end of treatment (day 14-21) to confirm PCR negativity; earlier if clinical suspicion of treatment failure
monitoring.action: If still positive: extend acyclovir 7+ more days; consider resistance

monitoring.frequency: Recheck at 2-4 weeks if relapse or new psychiatric/neurologic symptoms

disposition.criteria: NOT appropriate directly from ED for suspected HSV encephalitis — always admit. Discharge from hospital when: completing IV acyclovir course (or transitioned to monitoring); improved consciousness (GCS 15); no active seizures; stable neurologic exam; safe swallowing; rehabilitation arranged; follow-up confirmed
Mild encephalitis (GCS 13-15); stable; low seizure burden; able to cooperate with neuro checks
GCS <13; active seizures or status epilepticus; need for continuous EEG; respiratory compromise; signs of elevated ICP; hemodynamic instability
Need for neuro-ICU not available; need for neurosurgery (decompressive craniectomy); continuous EEG not available
Moderate-severe cognitive deficits (memory impairment, aphasia); motor deficits; able to participate in 3h/day therapy
Unable to tolerate intensive rehabilitation; requires ongoing nursing care
